millsfield:images_texts:
WAR DEPARTMENT
HEADQUARTERS NINTH CORPS AREA
OFFICE OF
THE AIR OFFICER
Presidio of San Francisco, Calif.
October 6th, 1925.
Excerpt from 1st Lieut.
H. A. Moore's letter.
"In reply to your letter of September 15th to Colonel F. P. Lahm,
who is at present away from the City on a short leave of absence,
enclosing herewith the
sketch which you
requested,
together with
some additional
information on landing field requirements and an
estimate of costs.
As the field stands to-day,
the runways - as I have placed them
are entirely
too short to accommodate all
types of planes.
If you want
to go into this matter in
the right way, the thing to do is to extend
the runways on out
into the marshy ground - making them approximately
fifty yards wide and as far Northeast and Southeast as possible,
bearing in mind
the high power lines and the fact that an obstacle at
the edge of
a field cuts off seven feet of runway for each obstacle
of its own height.
Perhaps three or four hundred feet
could be added
this way.
According to the
the prevailing winds
will permit
of landing into the Northwest and Southwest.
As the field is too small
for a runway from East to West,
I have placed the hangars,
shops,
etcetera,
along
the West edge of
the field next to the highway.
of hard ground must be dragged and smoothed before being
I would like to suggest
that if you care to look
into the future,
when you need a much larger airport, you might consider the proposition
of having the P. Go
marshland
& E. power lines removed and filling in
the East, thereby
providing a field with a one-half mile
runway East and West.
In such event the hangars could be located on
the North and South side of
the field.
You would then have a sufficient
area for every type of plane, together with a high factor of safety.
Any telephone, telegraph, or
power line around a field is a potential
menaceto landing and taking off."
properties.sfomuseum:airport: Mills Field Municipal Airport of San Francisco
properties.sfomuseum:description: Excerpt of correspondence from War Department, Headquarters Ninth Corps Area, Office of the Air Officer, Presidio of San Francisco, titled “Excerpt from 1st Lieut. H. A. Moore’s letter,” October 6, 1925, concerning existing conditions of potential airport site; typewritten page.
properties.wof:name: correspondence: Presidio of San Francisco, proposed airport site
